source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_007_chunk5
evidence_span: Displacive and Diffusional Transformations of the Beta Phase in Zirconium Alloys

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_007_chunk6
evidence_span: Phase transformations of zirconium alloys in the solid state are essentially governed by a few general tendencies. The high temperature $\beta ( \mathtt { b c c } )$ phase has the tendency to transform into the orthohexagonal structure, the orthorhombic distortion from the hexagonal symmetry depending on the extent of supersaturation with respect to $\beta$ -stabilizing alloying elements.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_007_chunk6
evidence_span: The $\beta$ phase also exhibits the tendency to transform into the $\omega$ -phase.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_007_chunk6
evidence_span: Another strong tendency which is responsible for several phase reactions in $Z \boldsymbol { \mathsf { r } }$ -alloy systems is the clustering tendency in the $\beta \cdot$ - phase. Spinodal decomposition, phase separation, monotectoid decomposition, metastable phase reactions during tempering of some martensites are all consequences of this clustering tendency.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_007_chunk6
evidence_span: Depending on the nature of alloying additions, chemical ordering in the $\alpha _ { i }$ the $\beta$ ,and the $\omega$ phase can be introduced.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_007_chunk6
evidence_span: 1. The high temperature $\beta$ (bcc) structure has a tendency to transform into the orthohexagonal structure at lower temperatures. While in pure zirconium and its dilute alloys, the low temperature phase is hcp, orthorhombic distortions appear in alloys richer in $\beta$ -stabilizing alloying elements which introduce a lattice distortion leading to the formation of orthorhombic martensite [2,47].

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_007_chunk6
evidence_span: 2. There is a tendency for the $\beta$ phase to undergo a transition into the hexagonal $\omega$ -phase in several alloys particularly when the $\beta$ -stabilizing alloying elements are present within a certain composition range.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: The observed orientation relation, being close to the Burgers relation, suggests that the correspondence between the $\beta$ and $\mathscr { X }$ lattices remains to be the same as what is observed in the case of martensitic transformation.

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: (i) The $\beta / \alpha$ orientation relation is very close to Burgers orientation relation

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: (ii) The habit plane pole (broad face containing the length and breadth directions) lies between $\{ 1 0 3 \} _ { \beta }$ and $\{ 1 3 1 \} _ { \beta }$ poles

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: (iii) The habit plane is decorated with periodic interfacial dislocations with a line vector along the precipitate length direction. The average spacing between the dislocations is about 8 to $1 0 \mathrm { n m }$

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: (iv) The length direction closely matches with the invariant line strain (ILS) direction $\langle 4 3 3 \rangle _ { \beta }$

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: Zhang and Purdy [25] using an extension of the O-lattice concept to a system containing invariant lines have shown that a complete Burgers vector balance can be accomplished at the $\alpha / \beta$ interface in $\mathrm { Z r } { - } 2 . 5 \ \mathrm { N b }$ by a single set of dislocations with the $[ 0 1 0 ] _ { \beta }$ Burgers Vector and a dislocation spacing of about $1 0 \mathrm { n m }$

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: The observed interfacial structure in $2 \mathrm { r } { - } 2 0 \ \% \ \mathrm { N b }$ ,however, differs from that predicted from the model for atomistic matching at the $\alpha / \beta$ interface in a similar system of $\mathrm { T i } { - } \mathrm { C r }$ alloys

source_id: STP1543-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_17th Volume_007_chunk8
evidence_span: Matching of the atomic planes across the $\beta / \alpha$ boundary in $\mathrm { T i - C r }$ alloy has been achieved by introduction of biatomic structural ledges with Burgers Vector $\left( 1 / 6 \ \left. \mathsf { a } \right. \right.$ and misfit compensating $\langle { \mathsf { c } } \rangle$ type ledges [26])

evidence_span: (iii) Shock deformation of $\beta$ -alloys [28,29]
